title: Will Toyota sell or lease more than 750 Mirai in the US in 2016?
preds: According to the general news and GJP consensus.
According to LeftLane.com Toyota has already reached this goal for 2016
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
for those that want to keep track of Kumamoto Japan earthquakes.  The Motomachi Plant was shut down after a 4.5 earthquake.     http://earthquaketrack.com/p/japan/kumamoto/recent
709 sold so far, 40 per month for 3 months remaining. Remaining uncertainty is due to the question of how and why the peak August sales came about, and whether that might be revoked in some way.

Sold YTD 710, monthly increasing sales record. Will make 40 a month for oct to dec.
So they will make in my view the 750.
Risk a manufacturing problem, I am not aware of. E.g. Batteries, or not enough components
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
An Earthquake in Japan could torpedo the 750.
Barring something freakish, it is almost a done deal already.
40 cars to go. Should be no problem.
710 ytd, which leaves only 40 needed for last 3 months. The drop in leasing costs seems to have really made the difference, especially as there as been no real change in the infrastructure.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

Toyota Mirai lease price drops to $349/month
http://www.autoblog.com/2016/09/21/toyota-mirai-lease-rate-dropped-349-month/

https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/336048
This should probably be enough to push it over the line and signals that supply is not an issue.

Not sure if someone else has already explained the jump in August but it looks like it was due to lower leasing costs and the main buyers were Toyota employees (http://www.greencarreports.com/news/1106296_price-cut-and-monthly-sales-spike-for-toyota-mirai-fuel-cell-sedan). This would suggest some cannabilisation of future sales, so my forecast may be too high, but with only 28 a month needed for rest of year, will drop it down to 96%, and await what numbers we get in September.
Upping to 92% to keep pace with consensus.
(no change) Any thoughts about possible effects related to the overall shipping problems?
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

To update those who haven't checked in on this question in a while, here's what happened. The August sales were 371 [A1]. That's 1.4x the previous months combined. Cumulative sales are 641, meaning an average of 27.25 sales/month will get this to 750.
371 units in August changed everything. Toyota only need to sell just over 27 cars a month.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

How do we find out who purchased these vehicles?  (Consumer, Business, or Government entities).  I was a bit reluctant to raise my forecast., but data talks and hunches walk.  At this point 113 are left ( making it what, 27 or so per month ).

Wow. August. Had to check the Toyota sales sheet.
http://pressroom.toyota.com/article_display.cfm?article_id=5692
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

This is what I have really been looking for.  It seems only 1000K Miria are forecasted to be sold in the U.S in 2016 and more than a 1000 people want one.  I figure the sales reports on a monthly basis are really based on production capacity.  watch how they are made  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oOUjqxec4bA
consensus is moving up.  staying ahead a few points
Toyota needs to sell 109 in the next 4 months so 27 per month.

This question is full of uncertainty.  Consensus at 10%.  State/Local government purchases supporting State emissions goals.  Heading into historical seasonal weak car sales period.  Too dangerous to be at 100% but will remain above consensus at 12%.  In reality the 750 will be very very close plus or minus 10?
August, unexpectedly, had  August 371 cars sold. Inexplicable. With 641 cars sold to date, 750 is most certainly in reach.
Initiating at 70% due to the spate of recent comments.

think I jumped too high.  The funds for the rebate programs are used up, or so it appears.  Perhaps high August sales represent a shifting of purchases to August that would otherwise have occurred later.  But - I really don't know.
Need 109 more sales (or leases) in four months, or at least 27 per month. We should get that, but I will wait until I see the September number before making an extreme forecast.

According to the general news and GJP consensus.
Deal with the state of California vehicles and Toyota sales figures for August 2016.

Entering question just for the points. Wonder why the consensus was so low, with so many clues as to this end of year uptick
http://www.hybridcars.com/california-governments-add-toyota-mirai-fuel-cell-cars-to-their-fleets/
August Toyota Sold 371 Mirai in the US, YTD 641!!! That leaves an average of 28 per month for rest of the year to achieve the 750 target, more than likely event. I was wrong, need to cut my losses
Just released numbers show 671 sold already this year

behind the ball on this.  Unsure if the huge August sales #'s are anomaly, but even if subside back to 40/month, will exceed the target.  And there are *some* vehicles around, though inventory looks lower than it was a couple months ago.

Anyone that has ever worked in Government will tell you that if you don't spend it you will lose it.  Considering the time of year we are in I suspected local/state governments would splurge on a Mirai or some other equipment that is not needed.  I found a nice little blog below talking about special deals for California.  Bottom line is this.  Government money is now spent.  The rest of Mirai sales will require people on a budget.  Considering historical trends and we are heading into a recession I find it hard to believe the Mirai will make it to 750 unless they cut the prices in half.  In which case I'll buy one and forgo my brier score.  But I will bring my forecast up to 10% just in case.  I will evaluate again once 3Q report comes out.
It the Christmas in September sell a ton

Toyota still has to sell 109 Mirai over the next 4 months for this question to resolve YES. If the 371 sold in August was a purchase by a company or local government, it will not be repeated in following months. They'll probably reach 750 by end of year but not certain.
Following the crowd. I'm glad I raised my forecast (a bit) after seeing the Time ad.

No idea what happened, but unless they are going to be correcting this press release (http://www.toyotanewsroom.com/releases/tms-august-2016-sales-chart.htm) it is a done deal. @dowser in case you haven't seen yet

August sales figures were surprisingly high with 371 cars sold. This brings the total up to 641 units. 
Need to reverse my estimate drastically up
http://www.goodcarbadcar.net/2015/09/toyota-mirai-sales-figures-usa-canada-monthly-yearly.html
moving to meet consensus for now, having trouble finding a good, outside view regarding typical timing and efficacy of sales incentives over the course of a year.
Not gonna happen.  Has anyone else noticed that Mirai sounds like the name of some ethnic group from Star Trek?  This is almost surely irrelevant.
Back down 5% on data from @67117mbz below.

According to the general news and GJP consensus. 
Less likely with lower gasoline prices.
holding for now, probably time to try to prove myself wrong. starting point may be giving more consideration to end of year incentives.

Going up 10% because I just happened onto a full page Mirai ad in Time magazine. They are offering it on lease for approximately $21k US for three years. This includes fuel for three years. Is this an attempt to get some buzz behind their brand and fuel cells in general? Are they planning to get enough on the road to test a little (bit more)? Is Time (tm) failing and just gave them a good deal on ad space?

Jan 26; Feb 30; 41 March, 41 April, 40 for May, 40 for June, 52 for July. 270 for year so far. At 50 per month for rest of year comes in at 520. Need 96/mth for rest of year to hit target.
file:///C:/Users/seamus.fagan/Downloads/TMS_July_2016_Sales_Chart.pdf
1% to stop myself being too dogmatic!!!!!!!!!!

270 units so far this year, which makes 750 remote but possible. It is late in the year for Toyota to expand sales outside California, so a new centre of demand to bump the data series appears unlikely. Even so, I can get ~15% chance of hitting 750 using an exponential growth model, but zero chance without assuming it is some sort of exponential process. I'm splitting the difference.
Very, very unlikely. In May I said sales will have to "catch fire." Now they need to explode. If some large corporation orders up 480 for a fleet, I will be proven wrong.
Dropping another 2% on July numbers of 52.

Toyota (TM) is delaying the launch in Japan of its plug-in Prius model by about three months. While declining to give a reason for the delay, the automaker now expects to launch the new model this winter with an initial production reduction.
July sales of 52 are a 30% increase on the Q2 average of 40 per month.
2016YTD sales are at 270.  The highest month is 52, though it is also the most recent month.
Down to 1% on no change in sales over the summer so far. http://www.goodcarbadcar.net/2015/09/toyota-mirai-sales-figures-usa-canada-monthly-yearly.html
Dropping after June sales. Still strongly suspect that it's a supply issue.

Reducing from 25% last month.
June US sales were 40, same as May and one less than the 41 achieved in March and April. Total this year so far is just 218, which means 532 more are needed in the remaining 6 months if 750 are to be sold. With the best month so far no more than 41, averaging 89 from now on doesn't seem likely. http://www.goodcarbadcar.net/2015/09/toyota-mirai-sales-figures-usa-canada-monthly-yearly.html
In accordance with Tinned Tuna's calculation of maximum cars possible this year being 613.
Linear model, r=0.69, N=9, (I think this is statistically significant) slope=2.37. Using this indicates that total sales for the year will be ~500. I should do an analysis of the variance on this...
Projecting 33% increase per quarter for a 2016 total of 630.
Down 5% since the consensus is dropping.
Dropping again based on latest sales numbers, but will only drop 2%, given that we are talking about so small numbers in absolute terms.
Not with the trend at ~40/mo. and I don't see things catching fire.
Mid year total for 2016 is 218 in total sales/leases.  The goal for 750 would require a jump from the current 40 per month to nearly 90 per month for July-December.
Currently on track for maybe 450.  They will only hit 750 by dint of a wild buying spree where nobody can live without a Mirai.  We are not dealing with Tickle Me Elmo here.
Down 5% to be closer to consensus.
Sales seem to have stabilized at about 40/month. Not sure if this includes leases. So unless sales go up soon, looks like they won't hit target
update: I edited the post to end-note citations/remove them from the body...
Dropping 3% based on May sales. The rest of my previous comment still holds. https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/239998
Highly unlikely. Monthly sales figures are averaging 35 so far this year, and I don't see any reason for them to pick up anytime soon.
Sales appear to have plateaued at 40 per month so a serious spike would be needed to get to 750-plus for the year.
Too high a proportion of the 2000 total to be produced. I would expect Japan to be the main market for 2016.
Looking at long term interest rates investors expect economies to slow down

I live in the target region in the northeast where Toyota apparently was hoping to sell these cars after their initial introduction in California. I am also the owner of a 2010 Prius, so you would think I would be near the bullseye for the target audience for the Mirai. However, I never heard about the car until reading this question for GJP. If that's the kind of marketing Toyota is doing, they'll never sell or lease more than 750 cars here.

Visited the closest hydrogen fueling station, which happened to be at a busy gas station.  Attendant said that ~10 people per day use it, which seems surprisingly high to me.  Guess I should go find out what other vehicles besides the Mirai - not sure I believe him that some of the cars coming through are Priuses.
Only 40 sold in May, down from 41 in March and April. [http://toyotanews.pressroom.toyota.com/releases/may-2016-sales-chart.htm]
Toyota now need to sell 81 cars a month or double their current monthly number to reach this target, dropping base line again.
Going on monthly figures so far.   http://www.goodcarbadcar.net/2015/09/toyota-mirai-sales-figures-usa-canada-monthly-yearly.html

Toyota (TM) suspended production at three Japan plants affected by an explosion at a supplier's factory earlier this week. The automaker expects full production to resume by the beginning of next week.

5 months into the year, and only 178 Mirai sold[1]. At this rate, only 427 Mirai will be produced this year.
This isn't on track to hit the 750 figure, I have to revise my probability sharply downwards. Using cumulative
moving average[2] to forecast the production rate, this is terrible. I wish Toyota's production team had read the Toyota
Way. Consensus is at only 10%[3].
I will look again at the end of June. The trajectory is flat for the last three months. Sales will have to really take off to reach 750 by year end.

May 2016 data keeps Q2 on 25% increase pace over Q1.
25% increase per quarter will be somewhere around 500 for the year.  Leaving room for change since the sales numbers are so low.
40 in May vs. 41 in April and March.  On track for maybe 450 so far.  Something dramatic will have to happen to get to 750--anybody got an inside line on this?
Infrastructure (or lack thereof) is still a big issue.
Apparent lack of fuelling stations. Toyota with holding figures and limiting sales.

On the plus
- Lentz, head of Toyota NA is still talking about this car
- fuel station constraints held up deliveries
- the Santa Monica hydrogen fuel station opened so LA (second market) is now going to start selling; might easily double sales to required rate
I still think this is a pretty low bar to surpass. Surely there are enough green 1%ers in CA who want to be big ticket early adopters for Toyota to reach this sales number.
The Case of the Missing Futures
Starting at consensus, although I think it's even less likely. I also think I am clueless, and can't even guess the right precedent.
$57k plus, people fear hydrogen, only selling in CA?, price and everything else point to get a Tesla or luxury hybrid.

750 is not a big number but sales have been weak implying lack of public awareness, infrastructure issues and competition. Starting with a low probability, will have to monitor and track monthly sale trends
better options available for that price
Hey, pretty sure I saw one in the wild yesterday!  +1 for that, even if the consensus has sunk yet lower.

I am changing my call after spending more time thinking about it. 750 is not a lot of cars, so a couple corp users or governments could change the direction, but the is expensive, not cool, and hard to get a hold of. Only advantage over other electric is 1) range and 2) fill up speed.

138 year to date, including 41 each in March and April.  They would need to average 77 per month the rest of the year.  Since the sales trajectory has not changed significantly for more than six months now, it it more likely than not that the sales pace does not turn sharply upward.  There are a few potential inflection points though - for instance if  stations are completed in late summer or early fall.  It seems unlikely the sales pace will change that dramatically in the next few months, but there is a non-trivial chance that it will.
138 have been sold to date in 2016.  I'm keeping conservative unless I see faster per-month growth over the summer.

Toyota reports it sold 41 Mirai hydrogen-fuel-cell cars last month (April), and 138 from January through April. Simple pro rata on annual basis that equates to 550 - although admittedly I have no idea the seasonality of car buying trends (anyone help?). Plus the fact quite a few equity analysts have a sell rating on the stock (I know a wider thing than just the Mirai, but surely not helpful), and the unhelpful reality that this car looks totally disgusting, I'm going low.

2016 will be terrible for auto sales. TM is leading the way down of all the auto manufactureres.
http://safehaven.com/article/41345/about-those-record-auto-sales-lets-communicate

Down 5% to be below consensus. Suspect that for whatever reasons Toyota is ramping up sales slowly. 3000 by the end of 2017 should be doable easily if they pursue this goal. Reaching 750 by the end of 2016 probably has no intrinsic value or meaning.
Consensus has fallen rapidly and want to go low on this one
Removing the 6% uncertainty and also dropping baseline by 2% on news that they only sold another 41 (http://pressroom.toyota.com/releases/april-2016-sales-chart.htm) in April.
Sales would have to accelerate a lot more than seems likely. There would have to be unsold cars sitting in dealer lots; and discount incentives. Let's see.

High price.
Rarity of refuelling stations.
Low sales through the first 4 months of 2016.
Projecting 33% increase per quarter for a 2016 total of 630.

138 Mirais have been sold through April, with 41 each in the last two months. http://www.goodcarbadcar.net/2015/09/toyota-mirai-sales-figures-usa-canada-monthly-yearly.html
Toyota will need to sell an average of 77 Mirais per month from now on to hit 750 before the end of December, almost double what they sold in March and April.

Barring government policy intervention the Miria will be competing with 2016 as a big year for EVs - infrastructure is likely to make it lag sales even for early adopeter of the green car of the year. Furthermore this model is a precursor to the next so sales volumes need not be a major Toyota target

Car is expensive. Aggressive contours, so people will hate it or love it. Very limited number of hydrogen stations in CA (13?, but planning to expand). Very tepid sales through April. Toyota itself is only hoping for a 700 sales target in 2016 (50 less than the IFP).
Down 15% on flood of factoids the last few days. Thanks.
Moving down to 30% from 44%.  I had moved it up because of concerns about pre-orders, but I think Toyota is committed to a go-slow strat.
No change.  From something with "gas" in its url, so might not be a friendly source, but wanted to compile some observations:

A linear regression of the available sales data estimates sales are increasing by ~2.6 vehicles per month, with a standard error of 1.6 vehicles. Even if I assume the true coefficient is one standard error above the estimate and do some rounding up, I get 592 vehicles sold in 2016. The rate could drastically increase, but given the buzz around the Tesla 3, I don't think it's likely.
Sales will really have to catch fire to reach 750 by the end of the year. They have 612 cars to go in the next 8 months, with peak sales so far of 41/mo. in March and April.
They would need to average about 63 per month to reach this goal, with a current YTD total of less than 140.  April's total of 41 sales was the highest yet.

They've had a great growth rate, but are intentionally slowing sales (or leases). The infra is still lagging what Toyota thought would be in place. I still believe that the possibility of ramping up in 2H is relatively high, but the question is will it be high enough to reach 750 for the year? Probably not.
20% based on lack of fueling stations.
Who would want one? Leasing seems more appealing than owning, but Toyota is not on pace to sell or lease 750 in the US this year. And there aren't enough fuel stations. Not much trunk space either.

Starting low as they need to catch up after first quarter. Also lack of publicity for car suggests Toyota in no great hurry to push sales until they are happy car is working well and hydrogen infrastructure in place
750 is too optimistic considering the early saturation of fully electric vehicles and the lack of Hydrogen stations.

With the lack of hydrogen fuel stations and competition from Tesla, 750 units seem a bit unrealistic. Sales are not on track to meet their own 1.000 target so far. The negative news surrounding the Mirai will make consumers think twice.

"Toyota says that about 90 percent of Mirai customers, however, are expected to choose the $499-per-month lease...Toyota expects it should be able to entice about 200 early adopters in the first year, ramping up to roughly 3000 total on the roads by the end of 2017"
http://www.caranddriver.com/news/2016-toyota-mirai-fuel-cell-sedan-photos-and-info-news

Not sure why I didn't research this earlier, but the northeast fuelling stations won't be operational before beginning of 2017 (http://www.automotive-fleet.com/news/story/2016/04/air-liquide-building-hydrogen-stations-in-the-northeast.aspx), so removing the 8% adjustment.

- hydrogen fuel station infrastructure lagging intentions, though more coming up between now and end of year.  Still, even many of the open stations are on "soft opening", where there might be delays at times.  Not sure whether stations are meeting opening quarter estimates or not.

97 cars sold year to date, with the rollout of hydrogen fuelling stations being the hurdle, its been so slow in fact that Toyota has asked dealers to slow down deliveries (http://wardsauto.com/alternative-evs-hevs-fcvs/lentz-tells-some-dealers-don-t-deliver-mirai-5?page=1). Depending on your source (http://www.marketplace.org/2016/04/11/world/toyota-makes-case-hydrogen-power or http://cafcp.org/) there are around 13-16 fuelling cells in operation in California at this time, with 6 more due to be operational by July, and 40 by year end. Toyota’s initial estimate of sales in 2016 was 1000 units, but they also expected 48 fuelling stations to be operating by end of 2015, and more to be built in 2016
So for California, taking 13 as a baseline supporting 97 sales, and Toyota deliberately trying to slow down sales at that number, and pre-orders willing to be patient in waiting for delivery (sorry can’t find the link for that but it was from an interview with a Toyota executive), it is not clear why it would make strategic sense now to accelerate the roll out in q2, or why customers would push for faster delivery, so if we assume a small increase on March run-rate, and take another 150 sold by July, this would then imply Toyota would have to stick to their run-rate plans of 1000 units per year ie 500 per half (assuming a straight line delivery which admittedly is a stretch) to achieve the goal of 750, but on a lot fewer stations. I would contend that this is unrealistic with a probability of only 18%.
Down 15% to be nearer the consensus.

750 vehicles seems like a low bar. Surely there must be at least 751 wealthy green people who want to be the cool kids by early adoption of this technology. Especially compared with all of the people who put down payments on that Tesla Model 3. Granted  fuel cells   sounds a bit dodgy (who wants to ride around sitting on top of tanks of hydrogen) but they have been hyped for years and in any case people have lived with gas tanks all these years (and battery fires for all electric vehicles).

Avg per month since inception is 28.17. But in 2016 the number has grown every month, albeit by only a few: 26-30-41, or 32.3/month. They need to get to 62.5 per month average over 2016. That is a tall order and will take continued and expanded growth. If the question were "in the next twelve months" i might be on the yes side, but i think the hole is too deep, and even one month of a regression or lack of growth will likely make it almost impossible.

Quite simply, Toyota expects to sell 3000 by the end of 2017, as such I think it reasonable to sell 750 in 2016.  Like the Tesla roadster, quite a few will be sold simply on account of the uniqueness of the vehicle, and regardless of hydrogen infrastructure.
However, should there be any major catastrophe with its operation (i.e. crash and explosion etc.) then I will revise for a lower estimate.

Difficulty in building refueling ubfrastructure coupled with higher cost of vehicle (vs. New Tesla) and lower (relative) gasoline prices makes this a difficult goal.  There is also competition from Honda for a new H2 vehicle, which may take some marketshare.
57,000/PER. Not a deterant. If Toyota can manufacture and deliver the buyers are there.

I am a bit high, but Bloomberg reported that there is a waiting list of drivers and most are just waiting for new stations. The free gas for three years promotion should also push sales. Selling 750 in LA seems at least possible, if not probable.
Not that they can't, but seems like they may not.

I'm pretty sue the land of fruits and nuts can produce at least 750 early adopters for the Mirai but there is a chance that safety concerns (the Hindenberg syndrome) and possibly an early safety failure will hold back 2016 sales. Early reviews are less than stellar and the fueling problems of scarcity and difficulty may come into play.  Range limits may also limit adoption -- but they said that about the Tesla and Tesla sold over 2,500 in its first year.

Corporate leasing will likely determine whether the 750 goal is reached. There are certainly lots of tech-savvy individuals who'd like to try this car, but tech ignorance among the broader population , as well as cost, will limit individual participation.
Moving up on @jaseuno's post about Mirari pre-orders.

Per http://www.hybridcars.com/toyota-mirai-goes-on-sale-with-2000-preorders/ Toyota intends to fulfill 1,000 Mirai order through mid 2017.  If that were done at an even pace, it would mean 667 cars in 2016 and 333 in the first half of 2017.  Since they also say they will provide 3,000 cars by the end of 2017, it looks like they are planning to ramp up production in 2017 and build many more in 2017 than in 2016.  This is also consistent with the fact they have only provided 97 cars through the first 3 months of the year.  At an even pace that would be about 400 in 2016.  Sales have increased each month, but the plant closing for the earthquake will temporarily stop that increase.
More and more folks are craving for non-fossil fuel cars.
Consumer interest sparked largely by Tesla will carry over to Toyota's entry.
They will sell if the infrastructure is available

Toyota projects the construction of 2000 Mirais in 2016. What's the lag time between construction and transport/delivery? And how badly will the earthquake slow things down? (And how closely will Toyota's production match its estimate?)
Up 10% because I want to be above consensus.

In November 2015, Toyota claimed to have nearly sold out of its 2016 supply with 1900 people wanting a Mirai in the US. (http://www.edmunds.com/car-news/toyota-ramps-up-production-of-2016-toyota-mirai-fuel-cell-to-meet-demand.html)
So far, the pace is about 400 for 2016.

Following @Raahul_Kumar It seems like early Tesla sales in California were driven by people with money and an interest in showing they were at the cutting edge. Priuses were so last big thing. I doubt either factor has changed and I would expect Toyota will get the Mirai into as many hands as they can to get real world experience. If I recall correctly, GM built 10k EV1's partly for that reason.
Based on figures so far, 750 seems like an unlikely number
Doesn't look good without new efforts.  Kind of a surprise to me since Prius did so well, but Mirai seems to be a dud so far.
It is difficult to imagine much demand in the short term for a relatively expensive car that is difficult to refuel and has a range of only about 500 km.  I am prepared to be wrong about this.

In 6 months 197 Mirai sold in the US. 
"Toyota Mirai FCV Declared 2016 World Green Car" might impact the sales but "Toyota — and Hyundai, for that matter — can only sell as many hydrogen-fueled cars as the fueling infrastructure can support. To date, Toyota has distributed only 100 of the 300 Mirais preordered in California for precisely that reason. Building out fueling stations is expensive and time-consuming. "
http://www.hybridcars.com/toyota-mirai-fcv-declared-2016-world-green-car/
http://recode.net/2016/03/23/fueling-the-success-of-the-hydrogen-powered-toyota-mirai-is-a-balancing-act/

From the link in "More Info", http://www.goodcarbadcar.net/2015/09/toyota-mirai-sales-figures-usa-canada-monthly-yearly.html, Toyota sold or leased a total of 169 Marais in the US between October 2015 and March 2016, with March being the best month at 41 vehicles. They will need to average 65 vehicles per month from now on to hit 750 by the end of December 2016.
Absolutely, no doubt about it, the Mirai has exceeded Toyota's sales projections from Day 1.

Rough estimate would indicate a rise to ~80-100 vehicles in December, which would correspond to 600-720 vehicles. All assuming linear growth and neglecting last years data. So starting rather low, however sales could pick up faster which would lead to a revisit of this estimate
